race.name: Barry Roubaix
race.tagline: The world's largest gravel race. 5,500 riders. Michigan spring chaos.

vitals.registration: Opens November 15 annually. Sells out in 24 hours. Cost: $79-119 depending on distance
vitals.aid_stations: Four aid stations for 62-mile, five for 100-mile. Well-stocked with water, snacks, neutral support.
vitals.cutoff_time: 100-mile has cutoffs: Mile 41 by 11:30 AM, Mile 62 by 1:15 PM, Mile 88 by 4:00 PM (~10 mph minimum)

climate.description: Historical race temps range from 20°F to 81°F—a 61-degree swing. In bad years (2017, 2022), DNF rates hit 40%+. In good years, course records fall.
challenges: Weather unpredictability is THE defining feature
Equipment strategy must account for all scenarios

terrain.primary: Seasonal two-track roads with sand, mud, and rocks
terrain.surface: Sager Road isn't gravel—it's an unmaintained seasonal two-track with sand ruts, mud holes, and baby-head rocks
features: Sager Road signature section (mile 18 on 36-mile, mile 60 on 100-mile)
Two unavoidable mud puddles on 100-mile at mile 60

gravel_god_rating.score_note: World's largest gravel race (5,300+ riders). Editorial +3 and overall +4 for scale and cultural impact.

prestige.explanation: Billed as 'the world's largest gravel race' since 2014. That claim is legit—no other gravel race fields 5,500. It's a Midwest institution and early-season benchmark, but lacks the gravitas of Unbound or SBT GRVL.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized for its massive size. Wave starts prevent complete chaos. Courses are well-marked with colored arrows. Aid stations are staffed with mechanics and EMTs. They've adapted smartly as field size grew.

experience.explanation: The combination of unpredictable weather, mass-start adrenaline, and post-race party creates memories. Surviving a cold, muddy Barry is a badge of honor. In good weather, it's a fast, fun day with friends.

community.explanation: Peak Midwest vibes. Hastings embraces the invasion of 5,500 cyclists. Founders beer tent. Food trucks. Live music. First-timers consistently describe it as welcoming and well-organized despite the chaos.

field_depth.explanation: Attracts regional pros and some national names. Ted King, Pete Stetina have raced here. The 62mi races 'like a road race' at the front with serious team tactics. Deep amateur field from Midwest cycling clubs.

value.explanation: $79-$119 entry for a professionally organized mass-start event with aid stations, marked courses, and a massive post-race party. Youth under 19 race free. No license required. Strong value proposition.

expenses.explanation: Michigan lodging is cheap. Hastings has budget motels. Drive from Chicago or Detroit in a few hours. No fancy gear required. Total weekend cost can be under $300 including entry, lodging, and food.

biased_opinion.summary: Barry-Roubaix is the world's largest gravel race for a reason. It's professionally run, technically challenging, and completely unpredictable. The weather roulette makes every year different. The community ownership makes it feel like home. The value proposition is unmatched in American gravel.
strengths: The scale: 5,500 riders from 48 states proves gravel's mainstream appeal
The value: $79-119 entry fees when other races charge $200-400
The community: Hastings owns this race. The town celebrates cyclists.
The unpredictability: Weather roulette makes every year a different story
The technical challenge: Sager Road separates prepared riders from hopeful ones
weaknesses: The weather: You can't control April Michigan. Bad years see 40%+ DNF rates.
The registration: Sells out in 24 hours. You can't procrastinate.
The distance options: Four distances means you need to pick the right one for your fitness.
The cold: If you're not prepared for 35°F conditions, you'll suffer.
The technicality: Sager Road breaks bikes and breaks riders who aren't ready.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want the world's largest gravel race experience with unmatched value and community support, Barry-Roubaix delivers. Just be ready for whatever weather Michigan throws at you.
biased_opinion.quote: World's largest gravel race. April Michigan weather. Sager Road. You'll remember this one.

black_pill.title: THE THING NOBODY TELLS YOU
black_pill.reality: Barry-Roubaix's 'World's Largest' status comes with asterisks. The weather is completely unpredictable—you can train perfectly and still DNF if Michigan decides to throw 35°F windchill and snow at you. The registration sells out in 24 hours, so you can't wait to decide. And Sager Road breaks unprepared riders—both physically and mentally.
consequences: Weather roulette means you can't know conditions until 48 hours before. Your equipment strategy, nutrition approach, and pacing all depend on a forecast that might change.
The registration window is brutal. If you don't sign up within 24 hours of opening, you're out. No second chances.
Sager Road breaks bikes. Sand ruts, mud holes, and baby-head rocks destroy equipment that isn't built for abuse.
The 100-mile Psycho Killer requires GPS navigation. If your device dies or you miss a turn, you're lost on an unmarked course.
April in Michigan means training through a Midwest winter. Most of your preparation happens indoors. The weather you train in won't match race day.
black_pill.expectation_reset: Barry-Roubaix is a fantastic race that rewards preparation and punishes assumptions. If you're ready for technical terrain, cold weather, and complete unpredictability, you'll have an unforgettable experience. Just don't expect California sunshine or smooth gravel roads.
black_pill.quote: You can train perfectly and still DNF if Michigan decides to throw 35°F windchill at you.

final_verdict.one_liner: World's largest gravel race where weather roulette and Sager Road separate the prepared from the hopeful.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes, if you want the world's largest gravel race experience with unmatched value and community support. Barry-Roubaix delivers professional organization, technical challenge, and complete unpredictability. Just be ready for whatever weather Michigan throws at you and prepare for Sager Road's abuse.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want guaranteed good weather: Unbound (late May, Kansas heat). If you want smooth gravel: SBT GRVL (champagne gravel, altitude challenge). If you want less technical: Mid South (red dirt, weather lottery but less technical).

logistics.airport: Gerald R. Ford International (GRR), Grand Rapids—26 miles, 30 min drive
logistics.lodging_strategy: Book immediately when registration opens—hotels fill with racers. Holiday Inn Express Hastings ~$107/night. Sharp Park Campground 10% discount with code 'BarryRoubaix'. Grand Rapids hotels 30 minutes away with more availability.
logistics.food: Hastings has restaurants but they're packed race weekend. Blackrocks Brewery Street Party post-race with bonfires, live music, food vendors.
logistics.packet_pickup: Cannonsburg Ski Area (April 12): Pre-ride, expo, $10,000+ gear giveaway. Hastings Ace Hardware (April 17): 2:00-8:00 PM. Race Morning (April 18): 5:30-9:45 AM at start line.
logistics.parking: Available near start line. Arrive early for best spots.

history.origin_story: Started as a local gravel race in Hastings, Michigan. Grew to become the world's largest gravel race with 5,500+ riders from 48 states and 9 countries.
notable_moments: 2022: 35°F with 19°F wind chill, 30 mph gusts, 43.1% DNF rate
2025: Perfect 58°F conditions, multiple course records broken, 21.1% DNF rate
history.reputation: World's Largest Gravel Race. The race that proved gravel could scale without losing its soul. On BikeExchange's bucket list. On GCN's Top Five.
random_facts: Sells out in 24 hours every year
100% of Blackrocks Brewery party proceeds go to Hastings Rotary Club
Youth 18 and under ride FREE for 18-mile and 36-mile distances
The 100-mile Psycho Killer requires GPS navigation (unmarked course)

course_description.character: Punchy, technical, unpredictable. Michigan doesn't do sustained climbs—it does 50+ rollers that hit you constantly. Sager Road defines the race's character.

suffering_zones.label: Three Sisters
suffering_zones.desc: Three consecutive punchy climbs immediately after leaving pavement. Primary selection point. If you're not with the lead group here, you won't bridge.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: First real test of the day

suffering_zones.label: Sager Road
suffering_zones.desc: 'Full of sand traps, rutted stony climbs'—the most technical section. Unmaintained seasonal two-track with sand ruts, mud holes, and baby-head rocks. This is the signature section that defines Barry-Roubaix.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: 100-mile version adds 'Big Papa' with more sand, more climbing, and two unavoidable mud puddles

suffering_zones.label: Chainsaw Massacre
suffering_zones.desc: Late-race technical section where fatigue meets rough terrain. Named appropriately—this section chews through tired riders.

suffering_zones.label: MAD WALL
suffering_zones.desc: The last (and hardest) climb. Signals the end is approaching, but you still have to get over it. 11% pitch with a false summit and 'fun little final pitch.' Many athletes walk portions.

course_description.signature_challenge: The weather. April Michigan weather spans 20°F to 81°F. You're gambling on conditions you can't know until race morning.
